chapter.name: Directives
chapter.title: Parser directives
chapter.description: some advanced features of text parser
chapter.intro: This chapter goes in deep on text format, dealing with the text parser advanced features.
chapter.section:
In text file you can embed other informations than just numbers: ∓ parser supports a syntax to specify parsing options and additional informations on stored data. User can specify informations like:
track organization, names, units of measure coding information like decimal separator char or column delimiters parser behaviour: error tolerancy, end of parsing postprocessing on retrieved data (resampling,reordering,rescaling,splitting)
Those informations take the form of parser directives that can be directly embedded in the text stream by the producer itself or passed as command-line argument when launching program (see below and related section).
Directives syntax is similar to those of C preprocessor: they consist of a specific keyword prefixed by the special character #; they can be eventually followed by a string argument, which consist of the trimmed string between directive keyword and end of line. Directives must not follow a particular sequence; see below for some examples.
Supported directives are:
Keyword Argument Description Remarks
#header string columns informations ordinate-abscissa relations, names, scales, units, delimiters
#resample index sequence definition resample and reorder modify samples sequence after parsing; indexes are referred respect shorter column and rescaled for the others; the scope is in the current data session
#split sequence of numbers split columns slice proportionally data columns; the scope is in the current data session
#title string title of plot frame shown in plot area; persists between data sessions
#xlabel string abscissa axis label in plot frame shown in plot area in place of current track abscissa label, persists between data sessions
#ylabel string ordinate axis label in plot frame shown in plot area in place of current track ordinate label, persists between data sessions
#xmarker number a vertical line in plot frame at a given abscissa persists between data sessions. See
#ymarker number a horizontal line in plot frame at a given ordinate persists between data sessions. See
#text (number;number) string a text label in plot frame shown in plot area at given coordinate, persists between data sessions. See . Prefix text string with + to show point coordinates.
#tolerant bool accept strange numbers like -. or E+ etc...; persists between data sessions
#decimalseparator char declaration of decimal separator char (ex. 1.2 or 1,2) override the global one defined in option; persists between data sessions. This directive neutralizes the curse of infamous locale settings
#thousandseparator char skipped character in number literals integer part used to ignore the thousand grouping character when converting number literals; use an empty argument to disable; persists between data sessions
#strictdelimiter char declare and pretend a rigid data delimiter with empty argument will be taken into account delimiters in header; persists between data sessions
#maxlines unsigned int maximum parsed lines parsing will end when line number exceeds this value; external appended lines are not taken into account; persists between data sessions
#end force end parsing
#header <x><y1(x)><y2(z)> #title Plot1 #xlabel angles [rad] #resample [20:30)[0:20)[30:2:100) #split 1|2|1 #decimalseparator . #thousandseparator , #tolerant false #strictdelimiter ; #xmarker 3.14 #ymarker 1.5 /* The following is a text label; prefixing text with + shows point coordinates */ #text (6.28;1) +Here ends period
// data start here 1;2;3 4;5;6 //...

section.name: Header
section.title: Header directive
section.description: declaring tracks names, scales, units, links

chapter.section:
The split directive allows to partition the original data columns, indicating with a seqeunce of numbers the proportion of slice sizes. For example the file:
#split 1,4 00 01 02 03 04 05 06 07 08 09
Is equivalent to:
00 02 01 03 04 05 06 07 08 09
This directive is extended also in case of more columns (though I can't figure in which situation this can be useful). The following file:
#split 2,1 00 10 01 11 02 12 03 13 04 14 05 15
Is equivalent to:
00 04 10 14 01 05 11 15 02 12 03 13
An automatic split is performed when an header declaring more columns as indexed ordinates is followed by a single column of data; in this case the single column will be automatically splitted according to specified indexes scale; for example the file:
#header <a([0.5])> <b([1])> <c([2])> 00 01 02 03 04 05 06
Is equivalent to:
#header <a([0.5])> <b([1])> <c([2])> 00 04 06 01 05 02 03
Or also, in the equivalent multiple session syntax:
#header <a([0.5])> 00 01 02 03 #header <b([1])> 04 05 #header <c([2])> 06

The resample directive applies to all retrieved data columns proportionally to their size. It enables a postprocessing activity to reorder and undersample data according to a sequence of indexes provided as argument. A sequence is composed by a chain of intervals, each interval is an arithmetic progression of indexes, characterized by a starting index, a step (1 if not specified) and an ending index. The progression contains always first index but not the ending index; this is denoted by the enclosing brackets that must strictly be [). Indexes start from zero and can be given as hard numbers or sums:
[0:100) count from 0 to 99 (0,1,2,...99) [6:2:13) count from 6 to 12 with step 2 (6,8,10,12) [4-1:2+1:10+3) count from 3 to 12 with step 3 (3,6,9,12)
Particular importance has the maximum index, representing the size of data to which indexes are referred. Resample indexes are automatically rescaled (except step) when applied to columns having a different size, so choose wisely the resample argument size to avoid rounding errors.
The best way to understand how this directive works is to see some examples. Let's see how to reorder some rows:
#resample [3:6)[0:3)[6:10) 00 10 20 30 01 11 21 31 02 12 22 32 03 13 23 33 04 14 24 34 05 15 25 35 06 16 26 36 07 17 27 37 08 18 28 38 09 19 29 39
Is equivalent to:
03 13 23 33 04 14 24 34 05 15 25 35 00 10 20 30 01 11 21 31 02 12 22 32 06 16 26 36 07 17 27 37 08 18 28 38 09 19 29 39
Now let's see what happens with different columns size:
#resample [2:5)[0:2)[5:8) 100 200 300 101 201 301 102 202 302 103 203 303 104 204 304 105 205 305 106 206 306 107 207 307 108 208 109 209 110 210 111 211 112 212 113 213 114 214 115 215 116 117 118 119 120 121 122 123 124 125 126 127 128 129 130 131
In this case only the third column match the resample argument size; the other columns are reordered rescaling resample indexes (except step equal to 1); the previous text file is equivalent to:
108 204 302 109 205 303 110 206 304 111 207 300 112 208 301 113 209 305 114 210 306 115 211 307 116 212 117 213 118 214 119 215 100 200 101 201 102 202 103 203 104 105 106 107 120 121 122 123 124 125 126 127 128 129 130 131
Note that in the previous example no rounding errors on rescaled indexes are occurred: in fact avoid these errors you must refer indexes of resample argument to the greatest common divisor of column sizes.
The resample argument notation supports also a step value; the following example tells ∓ to skip odd rows:
#resample [0:2:10) 00 10 20 30 01 11 21 31 02 12 22 32 03 13 23 33 04 14 24 34 05 15 25 35 06 16 26 36 07 17 27 37 08 18 28 38 09 19 29 39
Is equivalent to:
00 10 20 30 02 12 22 32 04 14 24 34 06 16 26 36 08 18 28 38
The resample feature does not (yet) support fractional steps (this would involve an interpolation function), so at present only undersampling is allowed.

Sometimes you may want a parser more fussy on data delimiters, consider for example the following data:
00 10 20 01 11 21 02 12 22 03 13 23 14 24 15 25 16 26 27 28 29
With the default sloppy delimiters policy the file would be actually interpreted as:
00 10 20 01 11 21 02 12 22 03 13 23 14 24 15 25 16 26 27 28 29
This is a consequence of the ambiguous delimiter definition, which does not provide any knowledge on columns position. It is possible overcome this problem in two ways: the first trivial workaround is rearranging columns in this way:
20 10 00 21 11 01 22 12 02 23 13 03 24 14 25 15 26 16 27 28 29
The second solution is declare a precise column delimiter, telling the parser to strictly expect a rigid data structure:
#strictdelimiter ; 00 ; 10 ; 20 01 ; 11 ; 21 02 ; 12 ; 22 03 ; 13 ; 23 ; 14 ; 24 ; 15 ; 25 ; 16 ; 26 ; ; 27 ; ; 28 ; ; 29
Now parser is aware of empty columns, so column 0 will contain only four numbers. Note that spaces between delimiters and numbers are still allowed, while spaces between numbers will result in an invalid number error.
As explicit developer choice the declared data delimiter must strictly be one char: a string delimiter would be a useless waste of space and parsing complexity.

section.name: CommandlineDirectives
section.title: Directives in command line arguments
section.description: passing directives as command line argument

chapter.section:
Directives can be embedded directly in the data file or, in case of need, temporarily appended using program arguments passed through command line. You can append additional lines at the top of a file that is going to be opened passing them before the file path argument, for example, given a file:
00 10 20 30 02 12 22 32
Calling program in this way:
C:\> MattPlot "+#header <a><b><c><d>" "+#tolerant true" data.dat
Has the same effect of opening this file:
#header <a><b><c><d> #tolerant true 00 10 20 30 02 12 22 32
Now a survey of typical errors. Sequence error:
C:\> MattPlot data.dat "+#header <a><b><c><d>" "+#tolerant true" C:\> ??ERROR: no file to append directives
C:\> MattPlot "+#header <a><b><c><d>" "+#tolerant true" data.dat C:\> Ok
Space in arguments error:
C:\> MattPlot +#header <a><b><c><d> +#tolerant true data.dat C:\> ??ERROR: what are `<a><b><c><d>´ and `true´?
C:\> MattPlot +"#header <a><b><c><d>" +"#tolerant true" data.dat C:\> Ok
